misconceptions.name: Reads three doubles for a different problem instead of 5 integers
misconceptions.description: The program prompts for 'v0, v1, and t' and reads three double values using nextDouble(), rather than reading five integers as required by the problem. This indicates the student is solving a different task (average acceleration) instead of adapting the input logic to read five integers for the sum-of-evens problem.
misconceptions.student_belief: I can reuse this code that reads v0, v1, and t as doubles to solve this question, without changing the input handling.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: For this problem, the program must read exactly five integers from the user, not three doubles. The input prompt and the number/type of Scanner reads should match the specification: use nextInt() in a loop or five separate calls to read five integers.
symptoms: Prompt mentions 'v0, v1, and t' instead of 'Enter 5 integers'
Program calls nextDouble() three times
User cannot enter five integers as required
misconceptions.root_cause: Likely copy-paste of code from a different assignment (average acceleration) and failure to adapt the input logic to the new problem requirements.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace the current input section with code that asks for and reads five integers, e.g., using a loop with nextInt(). Ensure the prompt describes five integers, not physics-related variables.
related_concepts: Matching program input to problem specification
Reading multiple values in a loop
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The prompt text and variable names (v0, v1, t) exactly match a standard average-acceleration problem, not the sum-of-evens task, and only three inputs are read.

evidence.note: Reads three doubles (v0, v1, t) with a physics-related prompt, instead of reading five integers as required.

misconceptions.name: Loop does not process inputs or iterate over the 5 numbers
misconceptions.description: A for-loop runs five times, but it neither reads new input nor processes different numbers on each iteration. Instead, it repeatedly assigns the same expression (v1 - v0) / t to x, which is unrelated to summing five integers.
misconceptions.student_belief: Having a for-loop that runs five times, even if it just recomputes the same formula, is sufficient to satisfy the requirement of using a loop.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The loop should be used to handle each of the five input integers in turn: on each iteration, read one integer, check if it is even, and update the running sum. The loop variable should control which input is being processed, not just repeat an unrelated expression.
symptoms: Loop header iterates 5 times (i < 5) but loop body does not use i
No calls to Scanner methods inside the loop
No per-iteration processing of different numbers
misconceptions.root_cause: Misuse of a copied loop structure without understanding its purpose, or a misunderstanding that merely having a loop satisfies the requirement regardless of what it does.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Move the input reading and even-number check inside the loop. On each iteration: read an int, test if it is even, and if so add it to a sum variable. Use the loop to process all five numbers, not to repeat an unrelated calculation.
related_concepts: Iterative processing of collections of inputs
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The loop clearly does not interact with inputs or any changing state; it only recomputes the same formula, which cannot implement the required per-number processing.

evidence.note: Loop runs 5 times but only reassigns x using (v1 - v0) / t; it does not read or process five separate inputs.

misconceptions.name: Missing even-number check using modulo
misconceptions.description: The program never checks whether a number is even; there is no use of the modulo operator (%) or any conditional that filters even numbers. As a result, it cannot selectively sum only the even values.
misconceptions.student_belief: The student appears to be focused on computing a physics formula and may not recognize that this problem requires checking each input with a condition to see if it is even.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: To sum only even numbers, the code must, for each input integer, test whether n % 2 == 0 inside an if-statement, and then add it to the sum only if that condition is true.
symptoms: No if-statements in the code
No use of the % operator
No branch that distinguishes even from odd inputs
misconceptions.root_cause: The student is implementing a completely different algorithm (average acceleration) and has not applied the required conditional logic for filtering even numbers.
misconceptions.remediation_hint: Introduce an if-statement inside the loop, such as `if (n % 2 == 0) { sum += n; }`, so that only even integers contribute to the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: The code contains no conditionals or modulo operations whatsoever, so it cannot possibly be checking for even numbers.

evidence.note: The core computation has no if-statement or % operator; it only computes (v1 - v0) / t.

misconceptions.name: Computes average acceleration instead of accumulating sum of even numbers
misconceptions.description: The variable x is used to store (v1 - v0) / t, a standard formula for average acceleration, and the program prints 'The average acceleration is ' followed by x. There is no accumulator variable that adds up even numbers, and the output message does not mention the sum of even numbers.
misconceptions.student_belief: This code for computing average acceleration is an acceptable answer here, or the student did not realize they needed to replace the physics calculation with a sum-of-evens accumulator.
misconceptions.correct_understanding: The program should maintain an integer (or long) accumulator initialized to 0. For each input integer, if it is even, add it to the accumulator. After processing all five numbers, print 'Sum of even numbers: ' followed by the accumulator value.

No sum variable that gets incremented
Output text refers to 'average acceleration' instead of 'Sum of even numbers'

misconceptions.remediation_hint: Replace x and the (v1 - v0) / t formula with an integer sum variable that adds even numbers read from input. Update the final println to match the required format: 'Sum of even numbers: ' plus the sum.
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Variable names, formula, and output string clearly match an average acceleration example and bear no relation to summing numbers.

evidence.note: x is repeatedly assigned (v1 - v0) / t and then printed with a message about average acceleration; no sum or even-number logic is present.

misconceptions.name: Loop not used to process multiple inputs or accumulate sum
misconceptions.description: A for-loop runs 5 times but does not read new inputs, does not use the loop variable i, and does not accumulate any sum. It simply recomputes the same expression x = (v1 - v0) / t on each iteration, leaving x unchanged from what a single computation would produce.

misconceptions.name: Missing Even-Number Conditional Logic

related_concepts: Type selection based on problem requirements
misconceptions.confidence_rationale: Problem explicitly states reads 5 integers, and student uses doubles instead. This is a clear mismatch. However, it is somewhat secondary to the bigger issue that the student is solving the wrong problem.

evidence.note: Input variables and loop counter are declared as double and use nextDouble()/floating-point arithmetic, when int and nextInt() are appropriate for reading integers.
